quest_title: \( \tan \left[ \cos ^ { - 1 } \left(\cfrac { 1 } { 2 } \right)+ \tan ^ { - 1 } \left( - \cfrac { 1 } { \sqrt { 3 } } \right) \right] = \)
explanation_txt:
\( \tan ^ { - 1 } \left( - \cfrac { 1 } { \sqrt { 3 } } \right) = -\cfrac{\pi}{6} \) and \(\cos ^ { - 1 } \left( \cfrac { 1 } { 2 } \right) = \cfrac{\pi}{3} \)

So,

\( \tan \left[ \cos ^ { - 1 } \left( \cfrac { 1 } { 2 } \right) + \tan ^ { - 1 } \left( - \cfrac { 1 } { \sqrt { 3 } } \right) \right] = \tan (\cfrac{\pi}{6}) = \cfrac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \)

[Use calculator.]
explanation_plain_text:
and

So,

quest_title: The area under the curve \( y = \text{sech} x \) above X-axis is:
explanation_txt:
Since \( \text{sech } {x} = 0 \implies x \to \pm \infty \), the curve is asymptotic about X- axis.

However, as the function is even, the area is:

\[ 2 \int_{0}^{\infty} \text{sech } x dx = 4\int_{0}^{\infty} \cfrac{1}{e^x + e^{-x}} dx = 4\int_{0}^{\infty} \cfrac{e^x}{e^{2x} + 1} dx \]

Let, \( u = e^x \) so, \( du = e^x dx \)

The integral becomes:

\[ 4\int_{1}^{\infty} \cfrac{du}{1+u^2} = 4\left[ \text{tan}^{-1} u \right]_{1}^{\infty} = 4 \left[ \cfrac{\pi}{2} - \cfrac{\pi}{4} \right] = \pi \]
question_plain_title: The area under the curve above X-axis is:
explanation_plain_text:
Since , the curve is asymptotic about X- axis.

However, as the function is even, the area is:

The integral becomes:

quest_title: The value of universal gravitation constant G = 6.67 \(\times\) 10-11 N m2 kg-2. The value of G in units of g-1 cm3 s-2 is
explanation_txt:
G = 6.67 * 10-11 Nm2 kg-2

= 6.67 * 10-11 * (kg ms-2) * (m2) * (kg)-2

= 6.67 * 10-11 *[ (1000 g ) * (100 cm) * s-2] * (100 cm)2 *(1000 g)-2

= 6.67 * 10-11 *105 *104 *10-6 g-1 cm3 s-2

= 6.67 * 10-8 g-1 cm3 s-2
question_plain_title: The value of universal gravitation constant G = 6.67 10-11 N m2 kg-2. The value of G in units of g-1 cm3 s-2 is
explanation_plain_text:
G = 6.67 * 10-11 Nm2 kg-2

= 6.67 * 10-11 * (kg ms-2) * (m2) * (kg)-2

= 6.67 * 10-11 *[ (1000 g ) * (100 cm) * s-2] * (100 cm)2 *(1000 g)-2

= 6.67 * 10-11 *105 *104 *10-6 g-1 cm3 s-2

= 6.67 * 10-8 g-1 cm3 s-2

quest_title: Two cities are connected by a regular bus service at an interval T in either direction with velocity \(\text{v}\). A cyclist cycling at 15km/hr from one city to another city find buses crossing him at an interval of 6 minutes and and bus passes him at an interval of 18 minutes. The velocity of each bus is.
explanation_txt:
Crossing

\(\begin{array}{l}{\cfrac{6}{60}=\cfrac{v \mathrm{T}}{v+15}} \\ {v \mathrm{T}=\cfrac{1}{10}(v-15) \ldots \ldots \ldots \text { (i) }}\end{array}\)

Passing

\(\begin{array}{l}{\cfrac{18}{60}=\cfrac{v \mathrm{T}}{v-15}} \\ {v \mathrm{T}=\cfrac{3}{10}(v+15) \ldots \ldots . \text { (ii) }}\end{array}\)

From (i) and (ii)

\(\begin{array}{l}{\cfrac{1}{10}(v+15)=\cfrac{3}{10}(v-15)} \\ {v+15=3 v-45} \\ {v=30 \mathrm{km} / \mathrm{hr}}\end{array}\)
question_plain_title: Two cities are connected by a regular bus service at an interval T in either direction with velocity . A cyclist cycling at 15km/hr from one city to another city find buses crossing him at an interval of 6 minutes and and bus passes him at an interval of 18 minutes. The velocity of each bus is.
explanation_plain_text:
Crossing

Passing

From (i) and (ii)

quest_title: A neutron is moving with velocity \(\text{v}\). It collides head on an elastically with an atom of mass number \(\text{A}\). If the initial kinetic energy of neutron is \(\text{E}\). The energy retained by it after collision is
explanation_txt:
\(E=\cfrac{1}{2} v^{2}\)
After collision,
\(v_{1}=\cfrac{\left(m_{1}-m_{2}\right)}{\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right)} u_{1}+\left(\cfrac{2 m_{2}}{m_{1}+m_{2}}\right) u\)
\(v_{1}=\left(\cfrac{1-A}{1+A}\right) v\)

\(\therefore K E^{\prime}=\cfrac{1}{2} \times 1 \times v_{1}^{2}=\cfrac{1}{2}\left(\cfrac{(1-A)}{(1+A)}\right)^{2} v^{2}=\left(\cfrac{1-A}{1+A}\right)^{2} \cdot E\)

explanation_plain_text: After collision,

quest_title: The thermal conductivity of a material in CGS system is 0.4. In steady state, the rate of flow of heat 10 cal/sec-cm2, then the thermal gradient will be
explanation_txt:
\(\cfrac { \Delta Q } { \Delta t } = \cfrac { K A \Delta \theta } { \Delta x }\)

Thermal gradient \(\cfrac { \Delta \theta } { \Delta x } = \cfrac { ( \Delta Q / \Delta t ) } { K A } = \cfrac { 10 } { 0.4 } = 25 ^ { \circ } C / c m\)
question_plain_title: The thermal conductivity of a material in CGS system is 0.4. In steady state, the rate of flow of heat 10 cal/sec-cm2, then the thermal gradient will be
explanation_plain_text: Thermal gradient

quest_title: If the refractive indices of crown glass for red, yellow and violet colours are respectively \(\mu _{r\, } ,\, \, \mu _{y} \) and \(\mu _{v} \), then the dispersive power of this glass would be
explanation_txt:
If \(\mu_{1}\) and \(\mu_{2}\) are refractive indices of the material of the prism for wavelengths \(\lambda_{1}\) and \(\lambda_{2}\), and \(\mu\) is the refractive index of \(\lambda\), which is the mean of \(\lambda_{1}\) and \(\lambda_{2}\), then dispersive power is defined as

\(\omega=\cfrac{\mu_{2}-\mu_{1}}{\mu-1}\)

quest_title: A compound microscope has lenses of focal length 1cm and 3cm. An object is placed at 1.2cm from objective lens then final image is forme3d at 25cm from eye. The separation of lenses is
explanation_txt:
\(\mathrm{v}_{\mathrm{o}}=\cfrac{\mathrm{fu}_{\mathrm{o}}}{\mathrm{u}_{\mathrm{o}}-\mathrm{f}}=\cfrac{1 \times 12}{1.2-1}=\cfrac{1.2}{0.2}=6 \mathrm{cm}\)

For eye lens \(\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{e}}=-2 \mathrm{F} \mathrm{cm}\)

\(\mathrm{u}_{\mathrm{e}}=\cfrac{\mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{e}} \mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{e}}}{\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{e}}-\mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{e}}}=\cfrac{3 \times(-25)}{-25-3}=2.67 \mathrm{cm}\)

\(\mathrm{L}=\mathrm{v}_{\mathrm{o}}+\mathrm{u}_{\mathrm{e}}=6+2.67=8.67 \mathrm{cm}\)
question_plain_title: A compound microscope has lenses of focal length 1cm and 3cm. An object is placed at 1.2cm from objective lens then final image is forme3d at 25cm from eye. The separation of lenses is
explanation_plain_text: For eye lens

The value of constant \(a\) will be
explanation_txt: \(\begin{array} { l } { \theta = a + \cfrac { b } { \lambda ^ { 2 } } } \\ { 30 = a + \cfrac { b } { ( 5000 ) ^ { 2 } } \text { and } 50 = a + \cfrac { b } { ( 4000 ) ^ { 2 } } } \\ { \text { Solving for } a, \text{ we get } a = - \cfrac { 50 ^ { \circ } } { 9 } \text { per mm } } \end{array}\)

quest_title: An observer is moving towards the stationary source of sound, then
ans1_txt: Apparent frequency will be less than the real frequency
ans2_txt: Apparent frequency will be greater than the real frequency

explanation_txt:
Apparent frequency when observer is moving towards source \(n'=\cfrac{n(v+v_{o} )}{v} \)

\(\therefore \cfrac{v+v_{o} }{v} >1\)

\(\Rightarrow\)\(\cfrac{n'}{n} >1\) i.e. \(n'>n\).

quest_title: Zener breakdown in a semi-conductor diode occurs when
explanation_txt: When reverse bias is increased, the electric field at the junction also increases. At some stage the electric field breaks the covalent bond, thus the large number of charge carriers are generated. This is called Zener breakdown.

quest_title: Water enters a house through pipe of diameter 2cm at pressure 4×10\({}^{5}\)N/m\({}^{2}\). A pipe of diameter cm leads to second floor bath room 5m above. The speed of water at inlet is 1.5m/s then pressure at outlet will be
explanation_txt:
\(\mathrm{A}_{1} \mathrm{v}_{1}=\mathrm{A}_{2} \mathrm{v}_{2}\)

\(\mathrm{v}_{2}=\mathrm{v}_{1}\left(\cfrac{d_{1}}{d_{2}}\right)^{2}=6 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}\)

\(\mathrm{P}_{1}+\rho \mathrm{gh}_{1}+1 / 2 \rho \mathrm{v}_{1}^{2}=\mathrm{P}_{2}+\rho \mathrm{gh}_{2}+1 / 2 \rho \mathrm{v}_{2}^{2}\)
\(\mathrm{P}_{2}=\mathrm{P}_{1}+0+1 / 2 \mathrm{v}_{1}^{2}-\rho \mathrm{gh}_{2}-1 / 2 \rho \mathrm{v}_{2}^{2}\)
question_plain_title: Water enters a house through pipe of diameter 2cm at pressure 4×10N/m. A pipe of diameter cm leads to second floor bath room 5m above. The speed of water at inlet is 1.5m/s then pressure at outlet will be
ans1_plain_text: 3.3×10N/m
ans2_plain_text: 1.5×10N/m
ans3_plain_text: 1×10N/m
ans4_plain_text: 2.2×10N/m

quest_title: A clock of pendulum gain 5 seconds in a day at 15\({}^{0}\)c and lose 10 seconds in a day at 30\({}^{0}\)c. The coefficient of linear expansion of material is
explanation_txt:
\(\cfrac{\text {gain in time in day at } 15^{\circ} \mathrm{C}}{\text { loss in time in a day } 30^{\circ} \mathrm{c}}=\cfrac{\cfrac{1}{2} \alpha(\theta-15) \times 1 \mathrm{day}}{\cfrac{1}{2} \alpha(30-\theta) \times 1 \mathrm{day}}\)

\(\begin{array}{l}{\text { or, } \cfrac{5}{10}=\cfrac{\theta-15}{30-\theta}} \\ {\text { or, } 30-\theta=2 \theta-30} \\ {\text { or, } \theta=60 / 3=20^{\circ} \mathrm{C}}\end{array}\)

Again gain in time in 2 day \(=1 / 2 \alpha \Delta \theta \times 1 \text { day }\)

\(\begin{array}{l}{\text { or, } \alpha=\cfrac{5 \times 2}{(20-15) \times 24 \times 3600}} \\ {=2.31 \times 10^{-5} /^{\circ} \mathrm{C}}\end{array}\)
question_plain_title: A clock of pendulum gain 5 seconds in a day at 15c and lose 10 seconds in a day at 30c. The coefficient of linear expansion of material is
explanation_plain_text: Again gain in time in 2 day
ans1_plain_text: 11.510/K
ans2_plain_text: 2310/K
ans3_plain_text: 4610/K
ans4_plain_text: 2.310/K

quest_title: Two tuning forks A and B sounded together produce 8 beats/s (c)'A' is in resonance with a column of air 32cm long in closed pipe and B is in unison with air column in closed pipe of length 33cm. The speed of sound in air is
explanation_txt:
\(\mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{A}}-\mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{B}}=8\)

\(\mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{A}}=\cfrac{\mathrm{v}}{4 \times 32 \times 10^{-2}}\)

\(\mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{B}}=\cfrac{\mathrm{v}}{4 \times 33 \times 10^{-2}}\)

\(\mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{A}}-\mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{B}}=8\)

\(\begin{aligned} \Rightarrow \quad \cfrac{v}{4 \times 10^{-2}} &\left(\cfrac{1}{32}-\cfrac{1}{33}\right)=8 \\ \therefore \mathrm{v}=& 8 \times 4 \times 32 \times 33 \times 10^{-2} \\=& 337.92 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{sec} \\=& 338 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{sec} \end{aligned}\)

explanation_txt:

Electromotive force \(=\cfrac{5 \mathrm{J}}{10 \mathrm{C}}=\cfrac{1}{2} \mathrm{volt}\)

quest_title: An ammeter of 10\(\Omega\) resistance has a scale of 100 divisions and indicates 1\(\mu\)A per division. It is converted into voltmeter reading 10v at maximum deflection. What is the resistance used in series.
explanation_txt: \( \mathrm{i}_{\mathrm{g}} =100 \text { divisions } \times \cfrac{1 \mu A}{\text {division}} \\ =100 \mu \mathrm{A}=10^{-4} \mathrm{A} \\ \text { Series resistance required } \\ \mathrm{R} =\cfrac{\mathrm{V}}{\mathrm{i}_{\mathrm{g}}}-\mathrm{G} \\ =\cfrac{10}{10^{-4}}-10=99990 \Omega \)
question_plain_title: An ammeter of 10 resistance has a scale of 100 divisions and indicates 1A per division. It is converted into voltmeter reading 10v at maximum deflection. What is the resistance used in series.

quest_title: A beam of well collimated cathode rays, travelling with a speed of 5 \(\times\) 10\({}^{6}\) m/sec, enters a region of mutually perpendicular electric and magnetic fields and emerge undeviated from this region. If \(\text{B}\) = 0.02 \(\text{T}\), then magnitude of electric field is
explanation_txt: \(\begin{aligned} V=\cfrac{E}{B} & \Rightarrow E=V B=\left(5 \times 10^{6}\right) \times(0.02) \\ & \Rightarrow E=10^{5} \mathrm{volt} / \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}\)
question_plain_title: A beam of well collimated cathode rays, travelling with a speed of 5 10 m/sec, enters a region of mutually perpendicular electric and magnetic fields and emerge undeviated from this region. If = 0.02 , then magnitude of electric field is
ans1_plain_text: 2 10 V/m
ans2_plain_text: 2.5 10 V/m
ans3_plain_text: 1.25 10 V/m

quest_title: A current of 3 Amp flowing in the primary coil is reduced to zero in 0.001 second, then the induced e.m.f. in the secondary coil is 15000 volts. The mutual inductance between the two coils is
explanation_txt:
\(E=M \cfrac{d i}{d t} \Rightarrow 15000=M \times \cfrac{3}{0.001} \)
\(M=5 \mathrm{H} \)

quest_title: The pH of a weak monobasic acid solution is 3 its dissociation constant is \(10^{- 6}\). the molar concentration of the solution is
explanation_txt:
Since the acid is monobasic, let it be \(HA\)

\(HA \rightleftharpoons H^+ +A^-\)

So, 

\(K_a = \cfrac{[H^+]^2}{[HA]} \\ \Rightarrow 10^{-6} = \cfrac{10^{-6}}{[HA]} \quad \left( \because [H^+]=10^{-pH} \right) \\ \Rightarrow [HA] = 1\)

quest_title: An element  x ( z=12) and another element y (z=8) combine together to from the compound. The molecular formula of the compound is
explanation_txt:
x y

1st shell: 2e-

1st shell: 2e-
2nd shell: 8e- 2nd shell: 6e-
3rd shell: 2e-  

Here, x forms octet by losing 2 electrons, and y by gaining by 2 electrons.

Thus, their valencies are 2 and 2. Thus the compound would be xy.

quest_title: A racing car is moving towards a high chiff. The car driver sounds a horn of frequency 'f' the reflected sound heard by the driver is octave higher than the original frequency. If v is the velocity of sound, then the velocity of car will be
explanation_txt:
Here, \(V_{o}=V_{s}=u(\text { say })\) and \(f^{1}=2 f\)
\(f^{\prime}=\left(\cfrac{v+v_{0}}{v-v_{s}}\right) \times f\)
\(\Rightarrow 2 \mathrm{f}=\left(\cfrac{v+u}{v-u}\right) \times \mathrm{f} \Rightarrow 2 \mathrm{v}-2 \mathrm{u}=\mathrm{v}+\mathrm{u}\)
\(\Rightarrow 3 \mathrm{u}=\mathrm{v} \quad \therefore \mathrm{u}=\mathrm{v} / 3\)

quest_title: Which of the following is not an acid salt ?
explanation_txt:
Acid should have ability to donate a proton\((H^+)\)

H of HCOONa is not replaceable, so it can not donate proton.

Except this all other can donate a proton.

 

Note : H of HCOONa is bonded to Carbon atom, so it can  not be replaced easily

but H bonded to oxygen is replaceable( as in -COOH)

quest_title: Ethyl benzene is prepared by friedal Craft's reaction. This is ---------- reaction.
explanation_txt:
The Friedel–Crafts reactions are a set of reactions to attach substituents to an aromatic ring.

Friedel–Crafts reactions are of two main types: alkylation reactions and acylation reactions

For substitution of ethyl group, alkylation is done.

For substitution of ethyl group, alkylation is done.

quest_title: The equation of the plane through the three points \( (1, 1, 1), (1, -1, 1) \) and \( (-7,-3,-5) \), is :
explanation_txt:
The plane passing through \( (1,1,1) \) is:

\( a(x-1)+b(y-1)+c(z-1) = 0 \quad (i) \)

Since,\( (1,-1,1) \) satisfies,

\( 0 -2b + 0 = 0 \Rightarrow b=0 \)

This eliminates (b) and (c). The answer should be (a).

So, the plane is \( a(x-1) + c(z-1) = 0 \quad (ii) \)

Since, \( (-7,-3,-5) \) also satisfies,

\( -8a - 6c = 0 \\ \Rightarrow \cfrac{a}{3} = \cfrac{c}{-4} \)

From (ii), the plane is \(3x - 4z +1=0\)

quest_title: If the resultant of two unit vectors is also a unit vector, the angle between them is:
explanation_txt:
Let \(\vec{u}\) and \(\vec{v}\) be two unit vectors whose resultant is also unit.

So, \( (\vec{u} + \vec{v})^2 = 1 \)

Or, \( u^2 + v^2 + 2uv \cos \theta = 1\)

Or, \(2(1+ \cos \theta) = 1\)

Or, \( \cos \theta = -{1\over 2} \)

So, \( \theta = 120^o\)

quest_title: The area of a parallelogram whose two adjacent sides are represented by the vector \(3i-k\) and \(i+2j\) is
explanation_txt:
The area of parallelogram is given by \(=|\overrightarrow{AB} \times \overrightarrow{AD} |\) \(=\cfrac{1}{2} |\overrightarrow{AC} \times \overrightarrow{BD} |\)

Here we are given adjacent sides and so \[\overrightarrow{AB} \times \overrightarrow{AD} =\left|\begin{array}{ccc} {i} & {j} & {k} \\ {3} & {0} & {-1} \\ {1} & {2} & {0} \end{array}\right|=2i-j+6k\]

Hence required area is \(=|2i-j+6k|=\sqrt{41} .\)

quest_title: A boat moves with a speed of 5 km/h relative to water in a river flowing with a speed of 3 km/h and having a width of 1 km. The minimum time taken around a round trip is
explanation_txt:
For the round trip he should cross perpendicular to the river.

\(\therefore\) Time for trip to that side \(= \cfrac { 1 k m } { 4 k m / h r } = 0.25 h r\)

To come back, again he take 0.25 hr to cross the river.

Total time is 30 min, he goes to the other bank and come back at the same point.

explanation_plain_text:

Time for trip to that side

quest_title: A ball is dropped on the ground from a height '\(\text{h}\)'. If the coefficient of restitution be '\(\text{e}\)', the height to which ball rebounds is
explanation_txt:
\(e=u / v\)
\(v=\) velocity of ball while hitting round
\(u=\) rebound velocity
\(\therefore u=e v\)

While falling,

\(v^{2}=2 g h \quad \therefore v=\sqrt{2 g h}\)

\(u^{2}=2 g h \quad \therefore u=\sqrt{2 g h'}\)

\(\therefore \sqrt{2 g h^{\prime}}=e \sqrt{2 g h}\)

or, \(h'=e^{2} h\)

rebound velocity
